TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit DesignerVerb extends System.ComponentModel.Design.MenuCommand

Docs.summary: Represents a verb that can be invoked from a designer.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A designer verb is a menu command linked to an event handler. Designer verbs are added to a component's shortcut menu at design time. In Visual Studio, each designer verb is also listed, using a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.LinkLabel>, in the **Description** pane of the Properties window.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerVerb> objects and add them to the design-time shortcut menu for a component.
[!code-cpp[DesignerVerb Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/DesignerVerb Example/CPP/component1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[DesignerVerb Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/DesignerVerb Example/CS/component1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[DesignerVerb Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/DesignerVerb Example/VB/component1.vb#1)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks Verbs are menu commands that are dynamically inserted into the menu at run time. Verb commands are usually displayed on either an edit menu or on a component's shortcut menu.

The event handler that performs the actions of the verb.
The starting command ID for this verb. By default, the designer architecture sets aside a range of command IDs for verbs. You can override this by providing a custom command ID.
